I hope this review isn't as long as a redditor's diary, but here are my thoughts on this game. Half-Life 2 is a great game. In my opinion it's massively better than Half-Life 1. The visuals still look decent and for 2004, they are fantastic. This game makes HL1 look like Space Invaders if you compare them side by side. This game feels like an adventure, which is very apparent during Highway 17. It also somehow feels open, despite the game being very linear. The game's difficulty is kinda inconsistent - some chapters are extremely easy, but other chapters (Nova Prospekt in particular) has some bullshit difficulty with stupid turret defense sections and a battle against 2 gunships where you barely have any cover. And last - the achievements. they are pretty easy to get, with the exclusion of Lambda Locator, which is very annoying to get.

My first experience with Half-Life 2 was on the Xbox 360 with the Orange Box. I loved and completed Portal and played Team Fortress 2 with my friends quite often, but somehow never got into playing Half-Life 2. I tried starting the game multiple times but never got into it. Years later and a new PC, I decided to buy the Half-Life bundle. I decided about 2 weeks(ish) ago that I was going to complete every Half-Life game. Half-Life 1 and the expansion packs were pretty good, but when I started Half-Life 2 again, it was different... in a good way. It went from a shooter game with a simple story, to an exploration shooter with a very different but fascinating story with great characters. You can tell that the developers did not want to be bound down by the previous game and wanted to try something new with the Half-Life franchise. I really enjoyed playing this game and I cannot wait to complete Episode 1 and Episode 2.

Half-Life 2 is an amazing journey from start to finish. I definitely recommend it to all gamers. 

On normal difficulty entering combat as a super soldier is engaging and fun. Battles with the enemy would often leave me scrambling for health and ammo. This greatly added to the game's thrilling nature. On a side not I also learned that I did not miss regenerative shields included by most modern shooters. 

The campaign features new weapons and mechanics compared to the original. They are expertly weaved in to solve puzzles and defeat enemies. 

Levels also feel large but not overwhelming. I admit i was lost a few times but never had to consult a guide to find my way.

I have a few critiques towards the game. The first and most annoying one is the addition of NPC's to your squad. I found they often got in the way, especially inside of buildings, and in combat they would often throw their lives away. This frustrating behavior made it extremely difficult to like them. 

My other gripe is having to cycle through the less impactful weapons in late game. The crowbar and SMG quickly get relegated by the superior gravity gun and assault rifle, but they are still first in the rotation. In Black Mesa i think the weapons in slots 1-4 felt equally useful throughout the campaign.

Anyway, HL2 is a great game. Just get it and play it.

[b][u]Long Version:[/u][/b]
For my 100th review on STEAM (and likely the last), [b]I decided to do something I've never done before; I played Half-Life 2.[/b] What followed was quite thematic; if STEAM is THE Valve Product, and this 20-year-old game got half-assed controller support for a portable computer very few people will want or afford, [i]just  to sell STEAM[/i], then what does that say about Valve?

Using Steam, (sorry, STEAM¬Æ)‚Äî and I mean [u]really[/u] using it, actually getting into it's features and design ‚Äîis a lot like playing Half Life 2. They are both time capsule's, untouched and ignored for decades, from a time when see-saw puzzles were mind-blowing. I can and DO remember the collective orgasm we shared the first time we dropped a cinder block on a bottle and it shattered. It's stilla thrill! Flawed, absolutely, but the innovations here were absolutely peak design at the time. It's impossible to put into context for younger people whata leap forward it was to have objects rolling under their own momentum, The last big shooters before this one only let you gun, more gun and knife. [SIC]  Half-Life 2 a landmark, and it holds up fairly well just like Steam, the first forever rental service.

[b]And I think the irony is that the people who created these things don't care.[/b]

There's been a lot of hay about competing services and fan games that are at best decent recreations and at worst offensive being tacitly honored by Valve's seeming disinterest in its very own intellectual property. There's the hilarious College Humor sketch about the CEO of OREO telling people "Guys? You can just stay home. We work at a money factory." That's Gabe. Yeah, that Gabe.

For a decade I've collected a laundry list of lacking features and petty annoyances, oversights and redundant features. How can something that almost never gets updated have so much cruft? What is all the money from my 550 purchases actually doing? Probably not much.
Headlines were made this very year that Half-Life 2 received it's first update in 18 years. The update was to add joystick support at long last. I don't think anyone tested the game, because the flashlight... The FRIGGIN flashlight... isn't bound to a controller button and cannot be bound without hacking INI files like I'm still using MUCKFOTHERING Windows XP.

What in the Jesus, Moses and [redacted] did they even DO? This game was on the 360, so  know they figured this out already. [b]I was determined to play though this entire game but quit just at the BOAT, not even getting the Gravity Gun, because the boat's gun was "<Not Bound>".[/b]

.... This game was made when we still had CRTs. Gaming was primitive as Hell, and didn't have even 1/100th of the money it has now. So, I think we cared a lot more. That's why people still dress up as Team Fortress 2 Characters, why "Cake is a Lie" is a joke your mom knows. The Orange Box and its contents [i]meant[/i] something to people. They still do. I still find new Indie games with nods to Half-Life in the form of all-powerful Crowbars. Half-Life2 was such a big deal, they had "Ready for Half-Life 2" stickers on computers being sold in stores.

[i]This[/i] game, Half-Life 2, made [i][u]all[/u][/i] of Steam happen... If that was mine? It would be my baby. I would keep in pristine condition. Even SKYRIM gets better content and updates decades later. Why not the most important PC game ever, (probably second only to DOOM?)

They probably know that nobody really plays this game anymore. That's reason enough to leave it behind I guess, but I don't think Valve understands that their properties are rotting away because [i]they[/i] let it happen. And it made me personally, [i]as a gamer[/i] ask what I'm still doing here.

Following up something like Half-Life with a game that manages to further innovate to this degree is nothing short of masterwork. There's so much packed into the relatively short story (by today's standards) that shakes up gameplay constantly. Gone are the claustrophobic halls of Black Mesa, embracing much more open environments to fight the cosmically powerful combine. G-Man is so fucking dope, truly unsettling considering his small appearances. Ravenholm is still very spooky! Father Grigori as this insane helpful uncle brings their trademark dry humour. The gravity gun is such a singularly interesting weapon that builds upon Valve's prop fetish. The only free man... right?

[b] THE GREATEST FPS OF ALL-TIME [/b]
When Half Life originally hit shelves back in 1998, it completely revolutionized the genre. It set a bar that would take years to surpass - the immersive storytelling, the amazing catalog of weapons and foes, all along with a unique blend of genres left many of us wandering just what this new company by the name of Valve could do next...

[i] ...then it came [/i]
JUST WHEN YOU THOUGHT IT COULDN'T GET ANY BETTER, Half-Life 2 dropped, and boy oh boy, what a sequel it was! Half-Life 2 took all the best parts of the first game, developed and expanded on them, and packaged it all up with that driving storyline and characters that you truly felt a connection with unlike any title before. The amazing fast-paced action, a plot that sucks you in and keeps you clicking not just for the addictive gameplay (of which it is *very* hard to put down) but also to find out what happens next. The best show you've seen on TV, your favorite page-turner of a book; the story in this game is [i] just as good [/i] as any of those, if not better. 

I just went back and gave this game a playthrough for the first time in over a decade and just - WOW! I can't believe this thing really lived up to all the great memories, all the nostalgia and wonder at the world Valve had created. Playing through in the modern day its hard to believe the engine itself is almost 20 years old. The game still looks and plays like any modern FPS.

[b] TO SUM IT ALL UP... [/b]
Half-Life 2 changed the course of video games. You should pick this title up and give it a playthrough if for no other reason than to pay respect to the video game that gave rise to titles like GTA, Halo, Call of Duty and more! If you've ever enjoyed an FPS that traded in polished cutscenes for an immersive story that felt like you were playing through a movie, this is the game you have to thank. Even all of these years later, the title holds up like a AAA heavyweight. Whether you've played the game dozens of times before or you're a youngster who's never touched the game before, do yourself a favor: pick up this title and enjoy the next ~20 hours of your life - you're witnessing history.

Players then journey through what feels like a buffet of exciting moments--from vehicular play, to battling large tripod-like robots, and co-op'ing with well-designed AI (Alyx and sometimes her companion, Dog) through an engaging, and non-invasive storyline.

What I love about all the Half-Life games is that the developers really know how to guide your eyes. A bad guy NPC could alarm you, only for you to see an amazing vista like a helicopter exploding. They're also good at disclosing story information in real time, without using cut-scenes or other typical narrative devices. The gravity gun adds a lot of creativity to an already exciting gameplay. HL2 seems to improve heavily upon what the original already did exceptionally well. 

The optimization is fantastic too. The game has minimal load times, despite showing off some amazing graphics and gameplay. My favorite level is, "We Don't Go to Ravenholm," which is one of the most heart-pounding Zombie-horror sequences I've ever played through. Simply put, the Valve team understands how to make games. I'll be playing this one again.

Dearest Player,

I hope this letter finds you well. I can hear your complaint already, "Gordon Freeman, we have not heard from you in ages!" Well, if you care to hear excuses, I have plenty, the greatest of them being I've been in other dimensions and whatnot, unable to reach you by the usual means. This was the case until eighteen months ago, when I experienced a critical change in my circumstances, and was redeposited on these shores. In the time since, I have been able to think occasionally about how best to describe the intervening years, my years of silence. I do first apologize for the wait, and that done, hasten to finally explain (albeit briefly, quickly, and in very little detail) events following those described in my previous letter (referred to herewith as Episode 2).

To begin with, as you may recall from the closing paragraphs of my previous missive, the death of Eli Vance shook us all. The Research & Rebellion team was traumatized, unable to be sure how much of our plan might be compromised, and whether it made any sense to go on at all as we had intended. And yet, once Eli had been buried, we found the strength and courage to regroup. It was the strong belief of his brave daughter, the feisty Alyx Vance, that we should continue on as her father had wished. We had the Arctic coordinates, transmitted by Eli's long-time assistant, Dr. Judith Mossman, which we believed to mark the location of the lost research vessel Borealis. Eli had felt strongly that the Borealis should be destroyed rather than allow it to fall into the hands of the Combine. Others on our team disagreed, believing that the Borealis might hold the secret to the revolution's success. Either way, the arguments were moot until we found the vessel. Therefore, immediately after the service for Dr. Vance, Alyx and I boarded a helicopter and set off for the Arctic; a much larger support team, mainly militia, was to follow by separate transport.

It is still unclear to me exactly what brought down our little aircraft. The following hours spent traversing the frigid waste in a blizzard are also a jumbled blur, ill-remembered and poorly defined. The next thing I clearly recall is our final approach to the coordinates Dr. Mossman has provided, and where we expected to find the Borealis. What we found instead was a complex fortified installation, showing all the hallmarks of sinister Combine technology. It surrounded a large open field of ice. Of the Hypnos itself there was no sign‚Ä¶or not at first. But as we stealthily infiltrated the Combine installation, we noticed a recurent, strangely coherent auroral effect‚Äìas of a vast hologram fading in and out of view. This bizarre phenomenon initially seemed an effect caused by an immense Combine lensing system, Alyx and I soon realized that what we were actually seeing was the research vessel Borealis itself, phasing in and out of existence at the focus of the Combine devices. The aliens had erected their compound to study and seize the ship whenever it materialized. What Dr. Mossman had provided were not coordinates for where the sub was located, but instead for where it was predicted to arrive. The vessel was oscillating in and out of our reality, its pulses were gradually steadying, but there was no guarantee it would settle into place for long‚Äìor at all. We determined that we must put ourselves into position to board it at the instant it became completely physical.

At this point we were briefly detained‚Äìnot captured by the Combine, as we feared at first, but by minions of our former nemesis, the conniving and duplicitous Wallace Breen. Dr. Breen was not as we had last seen him‚Äìwhich is to say, he was not dead. At some point, the Combine had saved out an earlier version of his consciousness, and upon his physical demise, they had imprinted the back-up personality into a biological blank resembling an enormous slug. The BreenGrub, despite occupying a position of relative power in the Combine hierarchy, seemed nervous and frightened of me in particular. Wallace did not know how his previous incarnation, the original Dr. Breen, had died. He knew only that I was responsible. Therefore the slug treated us with great caution. Still, he soon confessed (never able to keep quiet for long) that he was himself a prisoner of the Combine. He took no pleasure from his current grotesque existence, and pleaded with us to end his life. Alyx believed that a quick death was more than Wallace Breen deserved, but for my part, I felt a modicum of pity and compassion. Out of Alyx's sight, I might have done something to hasten the slug's demise before we proceeded.

Not far from where we had been detained by Dr. Breen, we found Judith Mossman being held in a Combine interrogation cell. Things were tense between Judith and Alyx, as might be imagined. Alyx blamed Judith for her father's death‚Ä¶news of which, Judith was devastated to hear for the first time. Judith tried to convince Alyx that she had been a double agent serving the resistance all along, doing only what Eli had asked of her, even though she knew it meant she risked being seen by her peers‚Äìby all of us‚Äìas a traitor. I was convinced; Alyx less so. But from a pragmatic point of view, we depended on Dr. Mossman; for along with the Borealis coordinates, she possessed resonance keys which would be necessary to bring the vessel fully into our plane of existence.

We skirmished with Combine soldiers protecting a Combine research post, then Dr. Mossman attuned the Borealis to precisely the frequencies needed to bring it into (brief) coherence. In the short time available to us, we scrambled aboard the ship, with an unknown number of Combine agents close behind. The ship cohered for only a short time, and then its oscillations resume. It was too late for our own military support, which arrived and joined the Combine forces in battle just as we rebounded between universes, once again unmoored.

What happened next is even harder to explain. Alyx Vance, Dr. Mossman and myself sought control of the ship‚Äìits power source, its control room, its navigation center. The ships's history proved nonlinear. Years before, during the Combine invasion, various members of an earlier science team, working in the hull of a dry-docked vessel situated at the Aperture Science Research Facility in Michigan, had assembled what they called the Bootstrap Device. If it worked as intended, it would emit a field large enough to surround the ship. This field would then itself travel instantaneously to any chosen destination without having to cover the intervening space. There was no need for entry or exit portals, or any other devices; it was entirely self-contained. Unfortunately, the device had never been tested. As the Combine pushed Earth into the Seven Hour War, the aliens seized control of our most important research facilities. The staff of the Borealis, with no other wish than to keep the ship out of Combine hands, acted in desperation. The switched on the field and flung the Borealis toward the most distant destination they could target: Arctica. What they did not realize was that the Bootstrap Device travelled in time as well as space. Nor was it limited to one time or one location. The Borealis, and the moment of its activation, were stretched across space and time, between the nearly forgotten Lake Huron of the Seven Hour War and the present day Arctic; it was pulled taut as an elastic band, vibrating, except where at certain points along its length one could find still points, like the harmonic spots along a vibrating guitar string. One of these harmonics was where we boarded, but the string ran forward and back, in both time and space, and we were soon pulled in every direction ourselves...

Okay, after putting it off for years at a time, I've finally beat Half-Life 2. Before you ask why, let me just say that a lot of this was due to time constraints, but also because this game just didn't pull me in the first few missions like everyone said it would have.

After putting it off for so long, did I feel like it was worth beating? Hell yes I do. Do I feel like it's better than the original Half-Life? God no.

Half-Life 2's ultimate goal vasts far from the concept of the original Half-Life. This isn't a bad thing, but it does leave some departments such as art & story to be quite lacking when you compare the titles together. Though in Half-Life 2's defense, art & story is not the #1 most important thing this game aims for; this game is really meant to show off the technical prowess of the Source Engine. In some chapters you can REALLY tell they were trying to let you know what was new about this engine. While I did enjoy the enhanced & refined gameplay, I really did miss a lot of the color & outstanding narratives Half-Life 1 had.

TL;DR - You should absolutely play this game in your lifetime, but in my opinion HL2 never set the bar higher than where HL1 had it at.

In my HL1 review I wrote it aged poorly. Thankfully, HL2 aged very well.
Objective improvements from the original:
- Great lighting effects and ambient sound design.
- Headshotting enemies is possible, so they are not as bullet spongy.
- Less aim punch from taking damage, making aiming for headshots easier.
- Fewer jumping puzzles.

Half-Life 2 is the progenitor of many 2000's tropes in FPS games:
- First person storytelling (while HL1 also had this, HL2 perfected it).
- Physics puzzles.
- A Gravity Gun-like weapon.
- Extended vehicle sections.
- Or even ammo crates with infinite ammo.

What HL2 excels at, compared to its brethren, is the immaculate sense of progression which gives you a feeling of being a part of a grand adventure. All setpieces, scripted sequences etc. are not too easy or too hard, and they last exactly as long as they should: not too short to make you starved for more, and not too long to overstay their welcome. Just enough to make you feel satiated and ready for the next one. The pacing is so expertly crafted it seems Valve has it down to a science. Also, the Shotgun and .357 are awesome.

What I don't like much:
- The Poison Headcrabs have too much health and their poison can grind the pacing to a halt, even if it does take only a few seconds for the HEV suit to administer an antidote.
- The parts in e.g. Anticitizen One, where a squad of NPCs is following you. They are frequently blocking narrow passages, which can be annoying.

No wonder people still love HL2 so much. It's just that good.

I first played this game at a weird time in life. Having grown up with a generation of games that were released well after HL2, and took MANY notes, playing it well over a decade after its release was odd. With gunplay that felt lacking in impact, and modelling/texture work that just felt *slightly* subpar to the time, (which is a massive testament to how advanced they were for 2004) I walked away feeling underwhelmed. Coming back to the game, once again almost a decade later, my initial reactions have been completely overridden. Keep in mind that I came back to HL2 using MMOD. With MMOD installed HL2's gunplay is perfect, and most of the issues I had with combat are gone.

       A lot of reviewers online imply that HL2 has been eclipsed by it's own influence on the gaming landscape. I agree with this to an extent. Games like Bioshock, Dead Space, Dishonored, Destroy all Humans, F.E.A.R. TONS of games really ran with the physics sim sandbox after HL2 proved that it could be done. These games pushed Half Life's ideas and in some areas did it better. Now? It feels like the industry doesn't really care about the concept anymore. What should have been turned into a standard, left as a gimmick. We get remakes of these games, sure, but coming back to HL2 feels like a breath of fresh air. Not to fall into the, "new thing bad/old thing good." mentality, but playing HL2 again makes me feel like a piece of the world is gone. It also really shows how much these devs cared. People can argue about valve politics all day, but the love that was poured into Half Life 2 was something special.

The Hog Rider is a fast ground troop with medium hit points, low damage, and the ability to jump over enemy Walls. He is unlocked at level 2 Dark Barracks.
The Hog Rider (person) is a bare-chested dark-skinned man holding a hammer. He has a Mohawk, wears a brown leather loincloth, a red belt, and a pair of leather sandals, as well as two large golden wristbands and a gold earring.
His ride is a large hog, about half his height. It has a brown leather bridle looped around its tusks, which in turn is held by the Hog Rider.
Hog Riders prioritize defensive structures above all other targets, and will bypass all other types of enemy buildings and troops while any defenses remain on the battlefield. This is true even if they are under attack by enemy Clan Castle troops, heroes or Skeleton Trap skeletons. Note that like all troops that prioritize defenses, Hog Riders do not consider the Clan Castle to be a defense regardless of whether or not it contains enemy troops, but do consider the defending Grand Warden and the activated Town Hall weapon (if any) to be defensive buildings.
Once all defenses are destroyed, Hog Riders become like any other troop with no preferred target; they will attack the nearest building to them regardless of type, and will turn and attack enemy units if they become aware of any nearby.

Offensive
He can be used to jump over any level Walls, rendering them ineffective against Hog Riders. Note that while this allows Hog Riders free access to what lies behind the Walls, it does not open up gaps for other troops to move through. If the Hog Riders need the support of other ground troops, you will still need to deploy Wall Breakers, a Jump Spell, or Earthquake Spells in order to assist them.
Hog Riders can be used en masse, i.e. a "Hog Rider Rush", without requiring any Wall Breakers to break Walls. However, such a strategy sports weaknesses against defending Clan Castle troops, Heroes, Giant Bombs, and Skeleton Traps, a problem which only becomes more prominent at higher levels.
At Town Hall 10 and above, Hog Riders can be combined with Miners in a strategy known as Hog Miner or Hybrid. Both troops are able to bypass Walls innately, but Miners do not have a preferential target, allowing them to cover for Hog Riders by dealing with defending Heroes and Skeleton Traps. The combination also has weaknesses against flying Clan Castle troops, as neither are able to target air.
At lower levels, Hog Riders are quite capable of acting as distracting troops like Giants; they have nearly as much health as a similar-level Giant, move twice as fast, and do considerably more damage.
They work well with the Healing Spell when you group several of them together.
A good tactic for using Healing Spells is to place them strategically on a cluster of defenses (at least about 3 or more) and also deploy them shortly before the Hog Riders arrive in the area, deploy them in front of the Hog Riders. This is so that the Hog Riders get the most value out of the Healing Spell, and destroy the defenses without losing too much HP.
Spots where Giant Bombs or Bomb Towers are/may be should be given special attention when deploying Healing Spells. Hogs of the same level as the Giant Bomb will survive a single Giant Bomb, but they're helpless against a pair of Giant Bombs even with a Healing Spell. Heal them after they've gone through a Giant Bomb blast.
The Hog Rider is one of the best troop types for drawing out Clan Castle troops, as it can avoid Walls to penetrate deep enough to reach centrally-placed Clan Castles (and enough health to not die before it gets there). Deploy one or a few to trigger the Clan Castle troops, then lure the reinforcement troops to the corner side, and deploy multiple Archers or Wizards to slaughter them, and then deploy the remainder of your Hog Riders. This strategy is especially effective during Clan War raids. However, Skeletons from the Skeleton Trap and Heroes can also easily kill the Hog Riders, as they can only target defenses, so make sure to have some troops that target anything, such as Wizards, which can swipe out the Skeletons.
Hog Riders don't target air so flying Clan Castle troops, especially Dragons, can be a big threat. Most mass Hog Rider strategies in Clan Wars require that the Clan Castle troops be killed first by luring. Bring other troops in addition to Hog Riders, such as Wizards, to deal with enemy Clan Castle troops and clean up the base.
Poison Spells can be used to kill almost any enemy Clan Castle troop, but beware as the troops will attempt to flee the poison. If the Poison Spells are decently leveled, and you effectively keep the Clan Castle troops from escaping the Poison Spell with distracting troops, they can eliminate almost any troop. They can also be used to dispense of those pesky Skeletons risen from the Skeleton Traps.
Time is also a factor to consider. With only 3 minutes in an attack, it is essential to make sure that this whole process and the remainder of the attack is done as quickly as possible to avoid running out of time.
Defensive
Defending against Hog Riders is tricky, as their ability to bypass Walls renders them irrelevant. However, the fact that they can jump over Walls and attack defenses means that they may leave behind their ground support (such as Barbarians, etc.), as they will not be able to follow. This will allow your interior defenses to concentrate on the Hog Riders.
Another way to defend against Hog Riders is to exploit the fact that they will attack the closest defensive building. You can arrange your base in such a way so that you have high-powered defenses on the inside and lower-powered defense on the outside, with a layer of resources in between. That way, the Hogs will (in theory) complete a loop around your base before being able to attack your interior defenses (Inferno Towers, X-Bows, etc.), by which time they should have all been killed by the interior defenses.
You can place Spring Traps and Giant Bombs in between defensive buildings to take out a few Hog Riders at a time; good usage of multiple Spring Traps and Giant Bombs can severely hinder a Hog Rider rush.
Hog Riders can be easily killed using "forced pathing". Forced pathing is a strategy that manipulates the Hog Rider AI and makes them go to at least 2 defenses that cannot be prevented by surgical dropping or side clearing. Placing a set of Giant Bombs in between the two can most certainly hinder the attacker progress. They would not be able to heal the Hog Riders in time.
Clan Castle troops, Heroes, and Skeleton Traps set to Ground Mode can be an annoyance to mass Hog Rider raids, as Hog Riders will not attack them unless all defenses have been destroyed. Make sure to centralize them if you want to beat Hog Riders.
In Clan Wars, Dragons are excellent troops to place in Clan Castles against Hog Riders, especially for Town Halls 8 and 9. They have high HP, meaning they won't die easily and can kill mass quantities of Hog Riders swiftly if not properly lured. Most mass Hog Rider strategies require that the enemy Clan Castle troops be killed first, so if the attacker lures out a Dragon, but fails to kill it, then a 3-star win is next to impossible, much less a 1-star win via destroying 50% of the buildings.
Multi-target Inferno Towers can be a severe hindrance to Hog Riders, having high HP to take several hits from Hog Riders, while hitting large groups of them.

The chapters themselves are a mixed bag for me, on one hand they can be really good like Nova Prospekt and they manage to make the Combine soldiers into pretty dangerous foes with their placements. The Miner card is unlocked from the P.E.K.K.A.'s Playhouse (Arena 4) or a Legendary Chest. He is a single-target, melee troop with both moderate hitpoints and damage that can be placed anywhere in the arena. He wears a dark grey helmet with a partially melted candle on top, carries a shovel, and has a large reddish nose and a slightly dirtied face. A Miner card costs 3 Elixir to deploy.

Strategy Due to his ability to be placed anywhere, the Miner can be used for surprise attacks on towers and troops. He deals only 30% of his normal damage to Crown Towers, so it is generally not recommended to use him on them alone. He can act as a surprise tank for high damage per second troops such as Wall Breakers. Spear Goblins or Minions, which is a cheap way to deal immense damage if ignored by the opponent. The Miner will tank the damage from the Tower or other troops while the supporting units deal chip damage. This combo can be countered by swarm troops or spells, however. A lone Miner can deal similar damage to a Rocket for half the price to a Crown Tower if ignored, so it is generally advised to address him whenever possible and reduce the damage he deals with each push. However, if one is using a high Elixir cost deck, it may be worth ignoring a lone Miner that is used to punish one's Elixir investment, so that they have more Elixir to create a large, unstoppable push. Compared to other 3 Elixir cards, he does not deal very much damage to a Crown Tower. The Electro Wizard works well with the Miner on offense. After the tower locks onto the Electro Wizard, a Miner can be sent in to tank for it when. The Electro Wizard's stun attacks will cause the tower to retarget onto the Miner, allowing the Electro Wizard to survive longer and deal more damage. You can also do this with the Zappies. If the player is sending the Miner to a Princess Tower, sending the Miner on the center tile of the inner side will allow the other Princess Tower to target him. This can be helpful in that the Miner is distracting both Princess Towers, so the player can send in fast backup troops to attack both lanes. However, if the Miner is being sent in alone, it is generally not recommended to deploy him here as he will simply die more quickly and deal less damage. On the contrary, due to this interaction, this placement is very effective when one only needs a few Miner hits to take down the tower, as many players will not expect this "self-destructive" placement. If the player deploys him in front of the tower, their supporting units are much easier to counter as splash units can easily splash the Miner and support troops. An Ice Golem can also be placed in front of tower pushing the Miner and forcing him to re-target. Due to this, it is not recommended to deploy him here, even as a surprise attack, as a unit placed far enough forward can take care of both the Miner and incoming support troops. If one wishes to attack the King's Tower without their Miner being within range of a Princess Tower, they should place the Miner on the left corner or 1 tile beside said corner of the King's Tower to avoid getting targeted by the right Princess Tower, and vice versa. Conversely, if one wishes to attack a Princess Tower without getting targeted by the King's Tower, place him in the bottom right corner of the right Princess Tower so that he can target it without getting targeted by the King's Tower, and vice versa. If the opponent has the Tornado card in their deck, they are able to drag the Miner to their King's Tower against many common placements, causing a King activation for an equal Elixir trade and very little Princess Tower damage. One should be aware of the two safe spots in which a Miner cannot be dragged to the King's Tower by the Tornado, those being the bottom-most tile on the non-King Tower side and the tile directly above that. Although a Miner is safe in these positions, this makes its attacks very predictable and easy to block with units as soon as the Miner is seen approaching. One may want to consider intentionally placing the Miner in a Tornado-vulnerable position and supporting him with fast, high damage units like Goblins or Bats. I'm surprised it's taken me this long to review Half-Life 2.  Basically, if you liked the original Half-Life, you'll like this.  Gameplay is similar, but with more advanced physics for its time.  The story is a continuation of the original Half-Life and the end, like the original, leaves you with more questions.  Pretty much every character is likeable and you meet a cool new friend at the beginning who sometimes supports you in battle.  I can think of about 4 weapons from the original that have been replaced with 4 new, different ones.  There are several enemies from the original that do not make an appearance here, but there are also several new, different ones.  None of the changes, in my opinion, make a negative impact on the game.

Now, considering this game by itself, it's really fun.  Lots of physics to play around with, lots of fighting, cool levels and good progression.  You wouldn't regret starting the Half-Life franchise here, but the references from the original would be lost on you, of course.

Then, there are the mods.  There are lots of fun mods out there for this game.  Some of my favorites are, in no particular order, MMod, Underhell, Nightmare House (1 & 2), Black Mesa, Grey and Cry of Fear.

Give it a shot.  I'm sure you'll have fun with this.
